newsitem.title: UZBEKISTAN: Cash-short Uzbekistan stops wheat imports - trader.
newsitem.headline: Cash-short Uzbekistan stops wheat imports - trader.

text.p: Uzbekistan has suspended imports of wheat targeted initially at 1.0-1.2 million tonnes this year, because it lacks hard currency, a grain trader said on Thursday.
"The delays in imports are due to a temporary lack of hard-currency which Uzbekistan needs to buy grain abroad," the trader told Reuters on condition of anonymity.
Uzbekistan, a largely desert Central Asian nation of 23 million people, consumes annually four million tonnes of bread-making wheat.
Last year the republic harvested 3.54 million tonnes of grain, including 2.73 million tonnes of wheat, and was planning to cover the shortfall of wheat with imports.
But traders say that Uzbekistan has missed the moment when wheat prices on international markets were relatively low.
He said that by May Uzbekistan had imported 150,000 tonnes of wheat from Germany at $193.5 per tonne and another 100,000 tonnes from neighbouring Kazakhstan at $207 per tonne.
The purchases were through the U.S. grain traders Cargill Enterprises Inc, he said.
Last year Uzbekistan bought around 1.6 million tonnes of wheat abroad, including some one million tonnes through Cargill and Switzerland's Glencore.
The trader said the government was expected to review grain imports after this year's grains harvest is gathered in late June.

"Anyway, the republic will have to resort to purchases on the world market, but the favourable price situation, when Uzbekistan could have saved $70-80 on each tonne of wheat, has passed," the trade source said.
An agriculture ministry official said on Thursday Uzbekistan could gather this year four million tonnes of grain.
The secretive former Soviet republic rarely reveals figures for grain purchases, a sensitive issue in the drive for self-sufficiency in grain it announced in 1995.
Its goal of producing at least 4.5 million tonnes of grain a year has remained far-off due to unfavourable weather, poor infrastructure and a lack of high-quality seeds.
